text: A grainy, low-resolution view of a dusty dirt road. We're low, just inches off the sun-washed ground, and moving fa ZOOMING down a street littered with the refuse of war: sp munitions, rubber bits, animal waste -- all of which, fro this odd, jarring perspective, looks gigantic, monstrous. We approach a crumpled COKE CAN, the white ‘C’ growing enormous on the screen, filling the screen like a skyscra SMASH into the can and barrel ahead. A RAG flutters, blocks our view, then flies away as we po over a bump, catching air and a flash of the horizon line BRIGHT SUN, then landing hard and continue zipping down t dusty road.
A rushed, disorderly evacuation. Iraqi POLICE and SOLDIER herd civilians away from some unseen danger.

A remote controlled TALON ROBOT (about a quarter million dollars of military-grade bomb squad electronics, aka ‘th bot’) whose SMALL VIDEO CAMERA we have been watching, dri down the side of the road on a pair of treads. Across the street, an Iraqi BUTCHER wearing a bloody whi smock resists being moved from his outdoor stand, which consists of little more than goat carcasses hung on metal hooks. From all sides, American military arrive in armored TROOP CARRIERS, disgorging teams of U.S. ARMY INFANTRY SOLDIERS shout “secure the area’, ‘watch your six,’ ‘stop traffic’ etc.

This is all taking place in a densely populated, very noi section of Baghdad; the SOUND of far off GUNSHOTS and CAL prayer magnify the turmoil of a metropolis in the midst o occupation/insurgency/civil war.
The BUTCHER, furious with the way he’s being pushed aroun is forcibly removed from his shop by several IRAQI SOLDIE

Via the low-angle video camera we glimpse a herd of GOATS scampering through frame. BURKA-clad WOMEN and OLD MEN in traditional garb flee the scene. Several more U.S. INFANTRY SOLDIERS move a few straggler PEDESTRIANS away from a trash pile and the TALON ROBOT. View momentarily blocked by STATIC INTERFERENCE. But when the screen clears, we close in on one particular TRASH PILE topped with a white plastic garbage bag. Whatever it is that has everyone so afraid lies inside th bag.
The TALON ROBOT pokes around the bag and the trash pile w its mechanical VISE GRIP.

Next to a parked Humvee, THREE EOD (Explosive Ordnance Disposal, aka Bomb Squad) SOLDIERS crouch over a laptop computer screen showing an image of the TRASH PILE. Working the joystick on the laptop is SERGEANT J. T. SANB a type-A jock, high school football star, cocky, outgoing ready with a smile and quick with a joke... or, if you prefer, a jab to the chin. Think Muhammad Ali with a rifl
I think we have touchdown.
The robot grinds the dirt, edging closer to the bag.

Standing near Sanborn, SERGEANT FIRST CLASS MATT THOMPSON wipes the sweat on his brow. Although he’s the team leade every inch the professional soldier working a routine mission, Thompson’s normally rock-solid nerves are waveri in the punishing desert heat. While nibbling on a SNICKERS candy bar, Thompson glances his shoulder noting potential threats: a WOMAN in a VEIL then TWO MALES in a window - all of whom are watching him with inscrutable expressions. Thompson turns back to Sanborn and the task at hand:
We glide across the pile. Flies buzzing. Puffs of dust and fluttering plastic. Advancing slowly, inch by inch, to the edge for our first glimpse inside the bag:

head_text.subj: A RUSTY ARTILLERY SHELL WITH A WIRE PROTRUDING FROM THE N

text: Hello mamma. Zoom in on the nose cone of the shell.
(re: the robot’s camera) Push it in.
I can’t.
What do you mean - you can’t? Pretend it’s your dick.
How about I pretend it’s your dick?

You'll never get it in if you do that. Let me try. A THIRD SOLDIER, clearly enjoying the two men he’s with, leans in for a better look. This is SPECIALIST OWEN ELDRI the youngest of the group, impressionable, vulnerable, ye quite capable of showing surprising backbone.
Give me a second.
No. Time is up. My dick. They change places. Thompson now on the controls. They ca see protruding from the rusty shell the tell-tale wire of Improvised Explosive Device (IED).
See that?
Nice one-five-five.
Yeah. That’s going to do some damage.
(calling over his shoulder) Hey Eldridge, we’re going to need a charge. Eldridge is already on it, approaching with the four bloc of C4 plastic explosive. He’s done this enough to know wh they need.
Got it. Figured four blocks, gives you about twenty pounds of bang total. Are we going to be far enough away? Thompson takes stock of the situation. We see the IED in distance -- far, far away.

The blast is going to roll out there (pointing) the shell will probably kick out there (pointing), and most of the shrapnel is going to rain up in a beautiful umbrella pattern. Some smaller pieces and shell fragments will come out this way but we’ll be okay if we are behind the Humvee. Bring the bot back and we will load up.
No problem. Bot is moving.
The bot dutifully makes its return voyage back to the men
A crowd of angry pedestrians is being held in place by a Iraqi soldiers, but when one soldier turns aside to help old man, the cantankerous BUTCHER slips past and dashes b to his store.
Eldridge clips a make-shift wagon to a hitch on the rear the robot. Inside the wagon, he’s placed an array of C4. Sanborn asks “ready?,” Eldridge replies “good to go.”

Alright. Wagon is set. Bot moves. The bot returns downrange, towing the cart and a coil of unspooling detonation wire, which Eldridge is holding. When... the HERD of GOATS from earlier circles back and momentari impedes the robot.
(laughing) Goats! Blow those bastards up.
The robot churns down the now empty street.
Thompson scans his surroundings, finds a third IRAQI MALE watching him from a nearby balcony. A flicker of concern flashes across his face.
The robot hits a bump and a rock jams in the wagon’s whee and breaks the lock nut, popping the wheel and causing th whole rig to grind to a halt.
Everyone cringes.
The wagon is stranded.
Sanborn wiggles the stick. It’s not happening.
Wagon is having a bad day.
(to Eldridge) Did you build that?
No, the U.S. Army did.
It looks like I’m going down there.
What, you don’t like waiting around this beautiful neighborhood? Thompson ruefully tosses his helmet into the truck.
I love it.

Sanborn unpacks “THE SUIT.” A state-of-the-art contraptio that looks like an astronaut suit and helmet crossed with Michelin Man. Because of its weight and complexity it tak two men to put it on - or one Sanborn. Sanborn kneels down and guides Thompson’s feet into the suit’s black boots, then lashes up a series of Velcro str to secure the armor, like a squire working on a knight. Thompson twists to get his chest protector on. Eyes tight brow furrowed, squints into the far distance. That's goin to be a mean motherfucker.
Okay. I’m going to make my approach. This area looks okay. No power-lines. Clean line of sight. If it looks alright when I get down there, I’m going to plug it in and we'll just BIP it. (MORE )
THOMPSON (cont'd) I want them to know if they’re going to leave a bomb on the side of the road, we’re going to blow up their little fucking road.
Ready?
I’m craving a hamburger, is that strange?
Not for you. Sanborn seals Thompson’s helmet with a glass plate while Eldridge attaches a breathing hose.
(headset from inside the helmet) This is Blaster One.
(into walkie) Roger that. Blaster One. You’re good to go. Thompson begins the lonely walk toward the bomb. Sanborn checks on the TWO IRAQI males in the balcony by glassing them with his M4 scope.
The men are smiling. Low threat.
Constrained by the eighty-pound suit, sweat in his eyes, Thompson LUMBERS down the road, emitting dust clouds with every step.
(headset) Nice and hot in here... One fifty.
(into walkie) Roger that. A hundred and fifty meters. An excited, blustering YOUNG IRAQI MALE, having just exit nearby building, approaches Sanborn with his hand extende greeting:
Hi, where are you from? Sanborn shakes his head, raises his rifle. The young man maintains a nervous grin.
No.
California? New York? Now they are standing close to each other.
Get out of here man.
Where?
This ain’t a fucking meet-and- greet. GET OUT OF HERE! Sanborn shoves the young man in the chest hard enough to nearly knock him over.

Go! The man skulks away, offended and confused. Eldridge -- who is about thirty feet away and inspecting burned out car -- notices this interaction out of the cor of his eye and keys his walkie to Sanborn:
Making friends again, Sanborn?  10
(smiling) All day long.

Thompson walks on. The desert sun glints off a nearby car and momentarily bleaches his mask bright white. A YOUNG GIRL with an INFANT BABY in her arms appears in a off doorway, then withdraws out of sight.
Eldridge and Sanborn are at the ready, scanning the area watching Thompson.
Thompson: careful footfalls on sand.
(headset) Twenty five.
Sanborn wearily keys the walkie.
(walkie) Roger, twenty five. You are now in the kill zone.
(headset) Thanks for reminding me. Eldridge nods. Everything progressing nice and easy.
Thompson stands over the blasting caps, picks them up and heads for the bomb.  11
(headset) Dets look okay.
(over walkie) Roger that. Thompson carefully lays the C4 on top of the IED.

(headset) Laying on the charge. (beat) ) Good to go, coming back. Thompson gets up, looks around at the empty road under he guard. The war has stopped for him and he knows it. Thompson begins to walk back uprange, looking carefully a the ground around him.
(headset) Five meters.
(walkie) Five meters, roger that.
Sanborn and Eldridge lower their rifles.
Thompson carefully nudges a Coke can out of the way of hi boots.
Eldridge, killing time, turns to Sanborn as they both wat Thompson.
Hey Sanborn, you know what this place needs?  12 Looking around the war torn dirt street, the mud colored buildings, and endless expanse of dust and sand. Nothing brown on brown.
I'm listening.
Grass.
We gonna start our grass business?
That's right. I’m going to sell the grass -- and you're going to cut it. It’s going to be called ‘Sanborn and Sons.’ We’ll be rich.
I like that. Crab grass, St. Augustine, I’m a scholar on this shit. How about this? You sell it -- I fertilize it. THOMPSON O.S. (headset) Twenty five.
(walkie) Twenty five. Roger that. Eldridge squints into the sun. Out of the corner of his eye he sees movement in the butc shop and raises his carbine.
The BUTCHER is holding a cell phone.
Hey Sanborn -- Butcher shop - two o'clock! Dude has a phone!
Make him put it down --  13 Eldridge runs toward the butcher shop. Sanborn raises his scope but Eldridge is blocking his lin fire and he can’t get a shot.
(shouting, waving his gun) Hey - put that down-- The BUTCHER nods and puts up his hand as if to say, ‘give a minute.’
Thompson senses trouble:
(headset) Why is Eldridge running? Come on guys, talk to me.
Eldridge runs hard
Drop the phone! Sanborn bolts sideways, trying to maneuver around Eldridg a clear sight line--
(shouting to Eldridge) PUT DOWN THE CELL PHONE! Burn him! Eldridge burn him! Eldridge, legs pumping, flicks the rifle safety--
The Butcher smiles. Gives Eldridge the thumbs up sign. His other handing dials the phone.
Sanborn sprinting but still can’t find a shooting angle. Eldridge is on fire:  14
Now Thompson starts to run. Terror in his eyes.
Prevented from locking aim on the butcher by two telephon polls.
The Butcher smiles back at Eldridge ECU: the Butcher's eyes. ECU: his thumb on send button of the cell phone.
Thompson running full out now when

-- A giant billowing fireball bursts from the bomb -- flattening Thompson -- blood splatters the inside of his helmet. Then: -- a secondary explosion erupts -- spewing dust and a wave of particulate matter -- enveloping Eldridge and Sanborn in a coarse cloud of debris. -- we stay on the blast’s aftermath as the last dust roil out in slow motion and -- floats silently over Thompson’s slain body  15

head_text.subj: INT CAMP VICTORY WAREHOUSE MORTUARY AFFAIRS

text: An officious young MORTUARY AFFAIRS SOLDIER opens the woo lid of a very white large box. Inside, wrapped in plastic, are the remains of a soldier' life: a pair of boots, a toothbrush, a comb, an American flag. Sanborn stares. Struggling to find meaning in the objects Now we see that he’s standing in a large warehouse, the mortuary affairs office, which is filled with rows and ro of many other identical white boxes.
Anywhere is good. Sanborn gently places Thompson’s dog tags in the box.
Is that everything?
Yeah. The white box closes. Latches secure the lid. And that’s that. The soldier walks away. Sanborn grips the box. He does not let go.
Sanborn trudges across a camp clearing which is bounded b the barracks and rows of identical aluminum trailers.

Inside a darkened standard-issue military trailer Ministr BLASTING, rattling the walls. Sanborn knocks on the door, hears “yeah, it’s open, come and steps inside.  16 He’s greeted by a MAN holding a roofing hammer in one han and a cigarette in the other. This is SERGEANT FIRST CLAS WILLIAM JAMES, his new boss. Sanborn extends his hand and they shake.
Sergeant James? J.T. Sanborn, my man.
Call me Will.
Welcome to Bravo Company and welcome to Camp Victory.
Camp Victory? I thought this was Camp Liberty.

No, they changed the name about a week ago. ‘Victory’ sounds better. An awkward silence ensues allowing us to get a better loo James. Though a former U.S. Army Ranger in his early thirties, fit and good-looking, one of the lucky ones, he possesses an unusual demeanor. In a world of outgoing you men, James seems markedly self-absorbed. Sanborn notices trait instantly and is puzzled by it. The truth is that a so many years down range, racking up kills and disarming bombs, James has lost some of the ability and most of the need to connect to other people. Right now, however, James is doing his best to act like a regular nice guy.

Alright. Well I guess I’m in the right place. (Beat) As long as you are here, could you give me a hand with this? James jerks his head to a window covered with a board of plywood. He walks over to it and starts removing the wood motioning for Sanborn to grab one end of the board.  17
Maybe you shouldn’t take this down. We get a lot of mortars at night here. The plywood helps stop the lateral frag from coming through. That’s why it’s up there.
It’s not going to stop a mortar from coming through the roof -- you know. Besides, I like the sunshine...(awkwardly) I’m sorry about Thompson, I heard he was a good tech.
Yeah, he was, and he was a great team leader too.
I’m not trying to fill his shoes. I'm just going to do my best.

Appreciate it. Although Sanborn is almost warming to his new Sergeant, J has reached his intimacy limit. He cranks the music, grabs his still-burning cigarette, a flops down on the bed -- all in one surprisingly fluid motion. Then announces cheerfully:
Home sweet home.

Sanborn is behind the wheel. James is in the passenger se Eldridge is in the back seat. Looking through the Humvee window, we drive past a long l of Ml Abrams battle tanks. They’re neatly parked and gathering sand on all horizontal surfaces.  18
Aren’t you glad the Army has all these tanks parked here, just in case the Russians come and we have to have a big tank battle.
I'd rather be on the side with the tanks, just in case.

But they don’t do anything here. Anybody comes alongside the Humvee, we're dead. Anybody even looks at you funny, we’re dead. Pretty much, the bottom line, is if you're in Iraq you're dead. How’s a fucking tank supposed to stop that?
Shut the fuck up, Owen.
(smiling) Sorry. Just trying to scare the new guy. James shrugs this off:
I saw a little bit in Afghanistan.
The Humvee moves out of the base and into the outskirts o the teeming city.
DAYS LEFT IN BRAVO COMPANY’S ROTATION: 38
Hey Owen -- watch the fucking road. The Humvee edges close to a cluster of cars. Eldridge mov up to the gunner’s seat on top of the Humvee.  19

Eldridge has a collection of half-empty water bottles tha keeps in the gunner’s nest. He throws a water bottle at the car in front of him. It smashes into the car’s rear windshield. A passenger inside spins, enraged. He sees the Humvee. Settles for a one finger salute for the American.
Imshee -- Imshee !

The Humvee grinds to a stop in a ghetto overflowing with trash, with more mud dwellings that look as beaten down a the people. James is first out, lighting another cigarette. Sanborn comes up behind him. Eldridge climbs out of the turret. They are now completely out in the open, feet on Iraqi ground, where anything can happen. Eldridge begins turning suspicious bits of plastic over w the tip of his boots.

(looking around at the empty street) Where are the guys who called this in? James walks on down the street. Sanborn and Eldridge exchange a glance ‘what the hell,’ a follow him. Meanwhile, in the background, Iraqi civilians go about th daily life.  20

(into walkie) Victory Main, Victory Main, this is Blaster Mike. Interrogative, do you have an updated position? DISPATCH O.S. (over walkie) This is Victory Main. Negative. Figures to follow. Grid 3453.

(into walkie) Well, that’s exactly where I am and I don’t see anybody in fatigues. DISPATCH O.S. Give me a second to confirm. That visual is 3453. James, Sanborn and Eldridge continue their slow walk down street. Around a corner, an empty Humvee comes into view.
We got a Humvee. On the other side of the street, Sanborn rounds the corne approaching the Humvee. He shouts in case someone is insi

Friendly! But there is nobody to hear him. The truck is empty. Eldridge looks inside the vehicle, checking for blood. James sees a tiny American flag being waved in the window a nearby building, and heads over to it.
(scared) They abandoned their vehicle.
(scared too) We got an empty Humvee over here!
Got it!  21
James peers into a garden where a half dozen young SOLDIE are resting and trying not to look afraid, and one SERGEA CARTER is trying not to look embarrassed.
Morning boys. Don’t tell me the bomb is in there with you.
Let’s step outside, I’1l show you what’s going on. He moves into the open and points down the block.

Down the block, about 20 meters this side of the mosque, East side of the street, one of our informants saw wires in a rubble pile - possible IED. I trust this guy, I know him. You want to talk to him?
I‘ll handle it. Keep your guys back. (to Eldridge) Specialist! Bring up the Humvee! Sanborn is already unloading the robot.
What’s going on?
Break out the suit.
What about the bot?
I'll take care of it.
What? Don’t you want us to get the bot down there to see what it looks like?
I’ll handle it.  22
It’s kind of tight down here, James. James grins. Sanborn shoots Eldridge a look. Is he a new or what?
Sanborn and Eldridge kneel before James, buckling on the suit.
You know you don’t have to go down there, man, we already have the bot half way out.
It will be alright. Sanborn puts the helmet on.
First day, I was thinking you might want to take it easy. Now enclosed in the suit, James is ready to go.

Let’s rock ‘n roll. James heads downrange, a jaunty bounce to his step. In stark contrast to Thompson’s cautious, lumbering gait, seems eager, almost happy, to approach the bomb. The guys watch him go.
He’s a rowdy boy.
He’s reckless.
Without warning, James tosses a round metal canister, a s grenade, into the middle of the street. ECU: canister jets explode, propelling a billowing cloud gray smoke.  23
Sanborn looks on in confusion as the dense smoke fills th street, obscuring his view of James.
(walkie) Blaster One, what’s going on? No answer. James disappears into the smoke.
(walkie) Blaster One, what are you doing? No answer.

(walkie) Blaster one, this is Blaster Mike. What’s with the smoke on the side of the road? No answer. SANBORN O.S. (walkie) Hey James, can you hear me? What’s with the smoke? JAMES O.S. (headset ) Creating a diversion. Sanborn can no longer see James through the smoke. He climbs up on top of the Humvee to get a better look. B he gets only a partial view.
(walkie) From what? Is there a threat? (to Eldridge) Get up on that wall. Tell me what you see, Specialist! Eldridge leaps onto a nearby narrow stone wall, feet precariously balanced.  24
I got him. He’s walking downrange.
(walkie) James, the smoke is killing my visibility. Where are you in relation to the IED? Are you within 100 meters, yet?

(headset) Hell, I don’t know. I’1l let you know when I’m standing over it. We see the world from James’ point of view: the city take an intense, dreamy hue as if somehow we're in some sort o fugue state. James walks on and the world returns to normal as he near intersection guarded on either side by a HUMVEE and sever SOLDIERS, when... Suddenly a red-and-white TAXI swerves past the SOLDIERS o the left side of the intersection. The soldiers take cover and shout contradictory commands “Stop the car” “Get Down Don’t Move! Back up! Out of the vehicle!” The TAXI BRAKES in front of James.
Sanborn and Eldridge can hear the shouting but the linger smoke still obscures their sight.
(shouting to Sanborn) Car! Car! A car stopped in front of him.
James’ headset barks to life:  25 SANBORN O.S. (headset) James, come back now. James pulls a pistol from his holster, aims it at the car
(over walkie) EOD has a nine on the Haji in the car. Should I send back up?
(headset) I got it. DRIVER’S FACE Impossible to discern whether he’s simply an annoyed taxi driver -- or a Jihadi on a suicide mission.
(into walkie to soldier) Negative, negative. You’re too close, the blast will come up the street. Stand down. Stay behind the corner. EOD has the situation under control.

James aims at the windshield. The driver is impassive. Soldiers shout, “get out of the car!” James SHOOTS two rounds into the dirt near the car’s fron tire. The Driver remains still. Staring back. James gestures with the pistol.  26
It’s that way...Back. James FIRES -- -- smashing the windshield into a million shards of glass But the car doesn't budge. Now James jams his gun into the driver’s forehead.
(into walkie) Three, four rounds fired. The nine is now pressing into the Haji’s forehead.
The driver slowly shifts into reverse and eases the taxi to the soldiers. Soldiers rush the car, yank the driver out and pound him roughly to the ground. The taxi driver is zip tied and dragged away.
(into mic) If he wasn’t an insurgent he sure as hell is now.
James resumes his walk, noting possible threats -- a MAN window down the road, TWO KIDS in another window.

One of a million in this city. James draws near. Two wire protrude from the mess. Moment of decision. Moving quickly, James removes rubble and trash to expose wires and the artillery shells.  27 He kneels down into the rubble pile. Touches the bomb. Then with great care, he removes the blasting cap from th bomb, making sure that it doesn’t make contact with the m edges of the artillery shell. He cuts one wire leading to the blasting cap. Then he flips the artillery round over and cuts the other wire.
(headset) We're done. Good to go.
Come down, Specialist.
Roger. Eldridge jumps from the wall.
James stands and uses his big boot to clear more rubble, revealing: Another wire snaking out of the ground.
(headset) Got a wire. Hang on.. James traces this wire, pulling it out of the ground, inc inch, like extracting a buried root. The more he pulls, the more wire gets revealed. It doesn’t seem to end.
Overhead, a YOUNG FACTORY WORKER on a high balcony studie James as he unearths the wire.  28
James, still pulling the wire, comes to a length that end a bundle of wires that spider out in several different directions.
(headset) Secondary! He pulls on this bundle and unearths a second IED. Then he finds a third IED. Then a fourth bomb. Then realizes he’s surrounded by a ring of IEDs.
This is the daisy-chain. One of the deadlier forms of IED
(to Eldridge) Off the wall, Owen! (to soldiers) Get behind something. Find cover. Soldiers scrambling to find concrete to hide behind.

The factory worker leaves his position and heads down the stairs. We follow him walking down the stairs, intercut with: James working on the bombs individually. ECU: James' helmet - glass clouding over from condensatio losing visibility. ECU: blasting cap EcU: feet on stairs ECU: knife tip separates the wire.  29
The factory worker is now on a landing, still heading dow
James notices the worker coming down and quickens his pac
The worker matches James’ accelerated movements, and is n rushing down the stairs.

The worker reaches the bottom of the stairs, opens the building’s front door, and steps into the street. He looks at James. James shows him the last blasting cap, indicating that th bombs have all been rendered safe. The worker reveals nothing. He turns and steps down an alley. As he goes he drops a 9 volt battery. We find a WIRE TERMINAL attached to the alley wall, where a different day the battery would have been connected to initiate the bomb.
James strides uprange. Eldridge isn’t sure what to make o James. Sanborn is, but not ready to show it. Sanborn unstraps the Velcro on James’ bomb suit, yanking roughly. This gets James attention.
That wasn’t too bad, for our first time working together. What do you think?
I think working together is I talk to you. And you talk to me.
Are we going on a date, Sanborn? Sanborn stands face-to-face with James.
No, we're going on a mission. And it’s my job to keep you safe, so we can keep going on missions.
Hey, this is combat. 30 James pats Sanborn on the shoulder, moves to the Humvee f Marlborough. Sanborn and Eldridge confer out of ear-shot.
It’s just thirty nine days.
Thirty eight. Assuming we survive today.
Electronic GRUNTS of a first-person shooter video game.
In a small recreation area, Eldridge, on a couch, plays G of War on a flat screen TV. LT. COL. JOHN CAMBRIDGE, a combat stress therapist, enter
Hey, it’s mister “Be all that you can be.” What’s up, doc?
Not much. How are you?
I’m good. I had a question about that song, though. What if all I can be is dead on the side of an Iraqi road? I think it’s logical. (MORE )
31 ELDRIDGE (cont'd) This is a war. People die all the time. Why not me?
You got to stop obsessing. Change the record in your head. Think about other things. Right now, what are you thinking about?
You want to know what I’m thinking about?
Yes. Eldridge picks up his M4 rifle, which had been resting on couch, and puts his finger on the trigger.
This is what I’m thinking about. Here’s Thompson dead. (Now he dry fires. CLICK. He snaps the slide back.) Here, he’s alive. Finger back on safe. He dry fires again.
He’s dead. He’s alive.

head_text.subj: EXT. CAMP VICTORY MESS TENT DAY

text: Midday in Iraq. The heat is oppressive, biblical. James is walking around the base when he’s stopped by a y Iraqi KID selling pirated DVDs. The kid, whose name is BECKHAM, is a street savvy punk.
Hey, wassup my nigger? You cool or not? You want to buy the cool shit? The tight shit? No? Fuck you! (he targets James) Hey nigger, buy some DVDs? New releases. Very good.
How much?
One for five, two for nine.  32
(having fun) Three for twelve.
Three for thirteen. And for you, no tax.
No tax? Alright.
You're a smart shit, you know. You're not like those stupid fuck face shits.
I’m a smart guy? You’re a smart kid. Give me your best one.
Here you go. This is the best shit. James pays. Offers a cigarette.
Keep the change. Want a cigarette? Are you kidding? You shouldn't smoke.

head_text.subj: INT CAMP VICTORY SHOWER STALLS NEXT MORNING

text: Sanborn is shaving in a mirror, otherwise dressed for com and ready to go. James shuffles in wearing a T-shirt and boxer shorts, loo like he just woke up. James starts to brush his teeth.
I need to talk to you about something before we roll out again.
Shoot.
Yesterday -- that was not cool.
I know. You’1l get it.  33 Sanborn wipes his face, trying to stay calm, notices a ta on James’ forearm.

You were a Ranger? I was in intelligence seven years before EOD. We ran combat missions in every shit hole on the planet. (beat) So I’m pretty sure I can figure out a redneck piece of trailer trash like you. James grins.
Looks like you’re on the right track.

head_text.subj: INT/EXT HUMVEE UNITED NATIONS TEMPORARY HEADQUARTERS MORN

text: The men drive into a parking lot teeming with people on t run, hundreds of UN EMPLOYEES, mostly white, many dressed business suits, flee the United Nations building. Parked beside the building is a blue sedan.

DAYS LEFT IN BRAVO COMPANY’S ROTATION: 37 The Humvee passes through a roadblock, stops, and James g out to talk to an IRAQI SERGEANT. Due to his current position in the parking lot, James can see the blue sedan that everyone is running from.
It’s behind the wall.
Did you see any wires? Any smoke?
No. I didn’t look.
So how do you know it’s a bomb?  34
The car has been parked there illegally and the suspension is sagging, so there’s definitely something heavy in the trunk.
Why don’t you peek inside and tell me what you see?
You want me to go close to it? In Arabic: you crazy piece of shit!

head_text.subj: EXT UN BUILDING NEAR SEDAN MOMENTS LATER

text: James now dressed in the bomb suit walks beside the Humve towards the blue sedan. Workers continue to stream out of the building, hurrying faster down a flight of stairs when they see James in the bomb suit. James comes to within twenty feet of the blue sedan. He stops.
On a third-floor balcony, unseen by the soldiers, a INSUR SNIPER takes aim.
-- a SHOT rings out -- bullet strikes the car -- it bursts into flames -- a plume of flame rushes out from the gas tank, like a blowtorch -- we see the flames through James’ helmet.  35

“It’s coming from over here”, shout INFANTRY on the groun outside the building as they FIRE M4s at the sniper’s balcony. Their bullets hit concrete, missing the sniper. A TEAM of SOLDIERS charges inside the building.
James backs away from the fire, toward Sanborn who is now running toward him with a fire extinguisher. Eldridge fol just behind Sanborn.
Sanborn passes James a fire-extinguisher to James.
I got top cover!

That's a negative, Specialist. Eldridge stay with me. Sanborn, you take top cover. It takes Sanborn an instant to process the insult: top co in this case, is the junior man’s job. Shaking his head, Sanborn runs to the building. Eldridge positions himself at the top of a staircase, hunkered down behind a low concrete wall.
James sprays the extinguisher into the roaring fire. Flam lick his suit.
Sanborn pounds up a long flight of stairs.
Gaining control of the fire.  36
Charges through the rooftop door and runs to the edge of roof.
The fire is nearly out, the car a smoking ruin, dusted wi white fire retardant powder.
At the edge of the roof, looking down over James and Eldridge.
(walkie) Blaster Mike in position.
James stops. He’s done. The fire is out. He looks up at Sanborn, nods. Then he wipes the car’s blackened window and looks inside the bad news.
Scans his surrounding, noting potential threats in every direction.

A salty officer, COLONEL REED, whose uniform shimmers wit military bling and Army skill patches, crosses the street a spot where an Army medic is treating the now badly woun SNIPER. Other SOLDIERS in Reed’s troop stand nearby.
(to medic) What have you got?  37
Through and through to the chest but I got him stable.
(smiling) He’s not going to make it.
If we’re leaving in fifteen minutes we got a survivable wound, Sir.
(giving an order to Soldier 1) He’s not going to make it. The Colonel turns away. Soldiers crowd around the MEDIC, blocking our view. We HEAR TWO SHOTS, killing the sniper -
The shots echo on the roof. Sanborn spins. Looks down to James.

James tries to use a crow bar to pry open the trunk but t fails. So he kicks the trunk with the bar, smashing it, until finally it squeaks open, revealing... a_trunk full of South African 155 rounds, linked with det cord. James is so taken aback that he drops the crowbar. Then he pulls the bomb suit’s quick release tab. The bomb suit falls away. Then he takes off his helmet.  38
(into walkie) What is he doing?
(into walkie) I don’t know.
What are you doing?
There’s enough bang in here to send us all to Jesus. If I’m going to die, I want to die comfortable. James passes the helmet to Eldridge.
I need my kit and my cans.
Sanborn stares down at James and the car. Great.
(into walkie) What’s going on?

(into walkie) I'm getting his kit and cans. (beat) Cover me, please. Eldridge runs to get the equipment, while James finishes removing his suit. Sanborn watches all this. Across the street, a young IRAQI MAN with a_ consumer VID CAMERA is also watching. He goes unnoticed.  39 Eldridge returns with the kit, hands it to James. James approaches the car and shines his flashlight into the tru Smoke. Wires. Bombs.
(into mic) Got a lot of det cord. Electrical. He snips a wire.
(into mic) I’m going to look for the initiator.
Nods, feeling vulnerable and exposed on the roof.
James gets into the back seat, presses the upholstery.
(into mic) It’s not in the back seat, I don’t think. He rips the upholstery with his knife. Tearing out foam. no wires.
(into mic) Nope. It’s not in the back seat.
Sanborn sees a YOUNG MAN on a balcony at 9 o’clock and wa to him while slightly raising his rife. The boy waves back.
(into walkie) I've got eyes on a young man on a balcony, at your 9 o’clock. Keep an eye on him.  40
Below, Eldridge raises his hand “roger that” - understood and nervously scans the surrounding buildings.
James in the front seat now rips apart the door, rips the weather stripping to just bare metal.
(into mic) It’s not in the front seat... It’s not in the door...not in the floors...not in the glovebox.
(into walkie) If you haven’t found it yet it’s probably under the car somewhere.
(headset) None of the cord goes under. It’s up here -- somewhere.
Sanborn keeps moving to avoid being a static target. Not liking this.
Eldridge now notices the MAN on a roof-top his 12 o'clock holding the video camera.
(into walkie) You got eyes on a guy with a video camera?  4l SANBORN O.S. (over walkie) No. Where?
(into walkie) He’s right at my 12 o’clock. You see him? He’s pointing the thing right at me!
Jabbing his knife into the upholstery.
(into walkie) Negative. I don’t see him.
Eldridge raises his rifle, motions for the man to leave. The man ignores him, keeps filming. Eldridge flips.
Right at my 12 - look 12 o'clock!
Sanborn jogs over to the side of the roof where he can no see the MAN that Eldridge is referring to.
(into walkie) Roger that, I got him. Yeah, he’s shady.
Eldridge lifting his gun.
(into walkie) So what’s the play?  42 SANBORN O.S. (over walkie) Be smart. Make a good decision. Off Eldridge’s panic:
Ripping wires in the car, increasingly frustrated, sotto voice “more wires going nowhere.” SANBORN O.S. (over walkie) Hey James, how you doing?
(into mic) I’m wonderful. How are you?
More and more, FACES are appearing in the windows around Sanborn and Eldridge.
(into walkie) We’ve been here a while. We need to get out of here soon. We got a lot of eyes on us.
James ignores this. He’s in a flow state, the athlete tot focused on the game. He retraces what’s left of the wire yet again. Thinking. SANBORN O.S. (over walkie) We got to get out of here.

(headset) Roger that. I’m going to figure this out.  43 SANBORN O.S. James, we need to get out of here. James ignores him. SANBORN O.S. James do you copy? James throws his headset walkie talkie out of the car.
It lands with a rattle on the ground.
(into walkie) I’m a sitting duck.
Sanborn sees below a SOLDIER helping an older woman out o the building. The soldier looks up to Sanborn and gives h thumbs up sign.
How’s it looking down there?
All clear.
(into walkie) The building is evacuated. We can leave, let the engineers handle this mess.
(into walkie) Are we moving?
(into walkie) That’s affirmative.  44
James pulls out the car radio. Suddenly -- The car’s rain wipers SCREECH and flap across the windshi
(sotto voce) Interesting.
What’s going on with James. He's not answering me.
I think he removed his headset.
(into walkie to Eldridge) Will you tell him to his radio back on.

(shouting to James) Hey James, Sergeant Sanborn is asking if you’ll please put your headset back on. James raises his hand and gives Eldridge the middle-finge ‘fuck-you’. ELDRIDGE (CONT’D) (into walkie to Sanborn) That’s a negative. It’s not happening.  45
Sanborn is pacing now, like a caged lion. He notices three MEN at a minaret behind him and waves to them.
I got eyes on three guys at the minaret. Six o’clock.
James keeps working. He gets out, checks under the hood o the car. Traces the wires there.
What the hell is he doing?
I don’t know - it looks like he’s checking the oil.
James pulls a wire. The windshield wipers stop their horr screeching. He goes back inside the car, checking under the steering wheel.

The angry MAN in the minaret that didn’t wave is now join by two other MEN, and they begin to point to Sanborn, and then down to James and Eldridge. They wave to the VIDEO CAMERA MAN. He waves back to them.
(into walkie) They’re communicating with your camera man.  46
(into walkie) This is bad. SANBORN O.S. (into walkie) Get behind a Jersey barrier.
(into walkie) I can’t keep eyes on James from here. Eldridge stands. SANBORN O.S. (over walkie) Get down. Now. Eldridge crouches back down. Not sure what’s right or wro anymore.
(to James) We can go!

James ignores Eldridge and continues to work. Finally, he finds what he’s looking for under a tangle of wires: a bl box. Slowly prying off the lid, taking it apart. Then he throws the black box. It goes flying out of the c James gets out. Shouts to Eldridge.
We're done... Sanborn, let’s get out of here! He picks up his headset, waves to Sanborn to come down of the roof.  47
Sanborn bangs open the door to the staircase.

head_text.subj: EXT UN BUILDING PARKING LOT MOMENTS LATER

text: James is flushed, red, sweat dripping as he approaches th Humvee, a big satisfied grin on his face. Sanborn, furious, charges him.

head_text.subj: INT UN BUILDING HUMVEE MOMENTS LATER

text: James gets inside the vehicle, lights up a cigarette.
That was good. Sanborn leans into the window.
Hey, James.
Yeah? Sanborn JABS him in the jaw, knocking the cigarette out.

Never turn your headset off again. Sanborn stalks off and James explodes out of the car. He crouches down, searching the floor of the Humvee. Sees cigarette, cleans it off, then goes back to his smoke. Once again, calm as can be, looking at Sanborn, consideri him. As James puffs away, watching Sanborn, two HUMVEE’s drive down the ramp to the parking area of the building. Several soldiers exit, among them is COLONEL REED. SOLDIE trot along beside him. The Colonel strides up to Eldridge.
You the guy in the bomb suit?
No, Sir. That's Sergeant James. He’s right here. (to James) Somebody here to see you. James comes around.
Hello, sir.
(to James, pointing) You the guy in the flaming car? Sergeant James?
Yes, sir.
Well, that’s just hot shit. You’re a wild man, you know that? The Colonel spins his head around to an aide.
He’s a wild man, you know that? (back to James) Let me shake your hand.
Thank you, sir.
How many bombs have you disarmed, Sergeant?
I’m not quite sure.
Sergeant, I asked you a question.
One hundred and seventy three. Counting today, Sir.
One hundred and seventy three? That must be a record. So tell me, what’s the best way to go about disarming one of these things? 48  49
The way you don’t die.
Good one. Spoken like a wild man. That’s good.

EXT CAMP VICTORY FIRST SERGEANT’S TRAILER AFTERNOON James, sitting on a bench under a camo net, grabs a smoke inspects a circuit board. A soccer ball rolls beside him. James picks it up. The DVD kid, Beckham, comes up to retr the ball.
Give it.
Wait a minute. Look who it is. I want my five bucks back, buddy.
Five dollars - for what? Are you crazy?
Those DVDs you sold me were crap.
No, you're crazy. That’s impossible. It’s Hollywood special effects.
It was shaky and out of focus, buddy.
Special effects! What do you want, donkey porn? Girls on dog? Just tell me what you want! Are you gay? You want gay sex? The boy’s chutzpa amuses James. He’s starting to like thi kid.  50
What’s your name anyway?
Beckham.
Oh yeah - like the soccer player? You good like him, too?
Better, my man. James gets up. Motions for the kid to give him space.
Alright, make you a deal. If you can stop the ball I’1l give you five bucks --
-- Five dollars? More like ten, twenty.
But if you can’t, I’m going keep the ball. Deal?
Deal. The boy runs to a makeshift goal post. James prepares to
Ready? One, two -- He kicks the ball in Beckham’s direction and it flies up Beckham blocks it easily. He’s very skillful.
-- three. Shit. Beckham comes back over to James, ball in hand, and notic the bomb patch on James’ uniform.
(pointing to the patch) Come on, where’s the five dollars. You are EOD. EOD -- boomala boomala. It’s fun, no? It’s gangsta? James is surprised by the question. Not sure how to reply  51

Yeah I think so. Tell you what, kid, I’'1l buy another DVD but if it’s shaky or out of focus or in any way not 100 percent, I’m going to chop off your head with a dull knife. (long beat) I'm kidding. James affectionately puts the kid in a headlock.
Eldridge is repairing something near the under carriage o the HUMVEE when the psychiatrist approaches.
How’s it going?
Good. Breaks are squeaky.
How you doing?
Good. Sleep is good. Eating well. Feeling pretty squared away.
Glad to hear it. You getting along with the men in your unit?
Yeah, my team is great. My team leader is inspiring.
You being sarcastic, soldier?
No. I mean, he’s going to get me killed. I almost died yesterday. But at least I’1l die in the line of duty, ‘Proud and Strong.’
You know, this doesn’t have to be a bad time in your life. Going to war is_a_ once in a life time experience. It can be fun.  52
And you know this from your extensive work in the field?
I’ve done my field duty.
Where was that - Yale?
Look, if you want to stop talking to me, you can. These sessions are voluntary. Eldridge considers this.
I appreciate what you’re saying. But you need to get out from behind the wire. See what we do.
If the circumstance calls for it, I will. Just like any other soldier.
We're at the south end of an EXPLOSIVES DISPOSAL RANGE, nicknamed, ‘Purgatory’ -- an empty expanse of dirt pockma with craters.
DAYS LEFT IN BRAVO COMPANY’S ROTATION: 17

A tremendous EXPLOSION, by far the largest we’ve seen yet kicks out a mushroom cloud of debris. We move across the field with the cloud and settle where EOD team is positioned by their Humvee. Sanborn has a remote detonator in his hand and is about t trigger it a second time.  53
Ready for second det? Fire in the hole. Fire in the hole. James cheerfully interrupts --

Hold on a second. I think I forgot my gloves back there. James jumps into the Humvee and drives down range, revers the course we just took. It’s a long way to the explosives, at least half a mile. Sanborn and Eldridge watch him recede in the distance. James is a tiny figure ambling around the explosives pile Sanborn looks down at the detonator in his hand. Eldridge notices the look.
(re detonator) Those detonators misfire all the time.
What are you doing?
I'm just saying, shit happens. They misfire.
He’d be obliterated to nothing.
His helmet would be left, you could have that. Little specs of hair charred on the inside.
Yeah, there would be half a helmet somewhere...specs of hair.
We'd have to ask for change in technique and protocol - make sure this type of accident never happens again. You’d have to write the report.  54
Are you serious?
I can’t write it.

No, are you serious about killing him? Sanborn stares at Eldridge. Dead serious. They look downrange at the their leader/tormentor. He’s recovered his gloves. He’s celebrating that fact by pumping his fists in the air.
Find the Humvee driving across the desert void. Driving a driving. Outside, horizon of sand and sun. Inside, shell-shocked men.

The Humvee crests a hill and comes in range of a HEAVILY ARMED MAN/face wrapped in a KEFFYIEH/nationality unclear, is waving an AK-47. Behind him are four additional ARMED MEN of uncertain nationality, as well as a large, disabled SUV.
In the turret, Eldridge fingers the trigger of his .50 machine gun.
(shouting below) Roger that. 12 o'clock. I see an SUV. I got four armed men. They’re in Haji gear.  55
Careful now, guys. (to James) We're in it now.
Eldridge, stay on that fifty.

The keffiyeh-clad man stops waving his arms, and walks towards the HUMVEE. Sanborn brakes. James and Sanborn charge out of the vehicle, blood boilin guns high, yelling: DROP YOUR FUCKING GUNS! HANDS UP! ON
The keffiyeh man does not comply. Instead, he shouts a re that is drowned out by the desert wind.
Hands high!
Eldridge, cover!
I got you! Sanborn continues shouting orders: GET DOWN NOW! ON YOUR

Finally, the keffiyeh man nods to his men, who lower thei prodigious weapons. Then he takes his own piece...and carefully unsnaps it fr the shoulder sling. He kneels and interlaces his hands on his head. As James and Eldridge provide cover, Sanborn rushes forwa shaking with adrenaline, M4 darting back and forth. When he’s close, Sanborn notices a pistol still strapped the man’s leg.
Pistol - take it off now.  56
(in English) What do you want me to do, put my hands up or take off my pistol?
Keep your hands up.
Okay. Sanborn reaches for his pistol. It catches in the holster then comes free.
Can I touch my fucking head now?

Slowly. Slowly unfurling his Keffiyeh... Until we see that he’s not at all Arabic but just a darkl tanned, bearded Anglo-Saxon: a former member of the Briti SAS turned MERCENARY TEAM LEADER -- who at this moment is feeling pretty sick of American yahoos.
We're on the same side. You guys are wired tight - you know that?
What are you doing out here? This is no place for a picnic.
We've got a flat tire. Can you help us?
Sure. Do you have spares?
We have a spare but we used up our wrench.
How do you use up a wrench?
(pointing to FEISAL, one of the mercenaries) That guy - he threw it at someone.  57
(to FEISAL) You know you don’t have to throw wrenches. You can shoot people here.
Fuck off. They walk back to the contractor’s vehicle, where two ENE PRISONERS OF WAR (EPWs, or so we assume), shrouded in bla hoods, hands bound, are kneeling uncomfortably on the des floor.

A moment of calm: FEISAL crouches by the SUV’s flat tire, twisting a wrench A second mercenary - call him JIMMY - gives a drink of wa to the two bound and hooded EPWs. The two remaining mercenaries, CHRIS and CHARLIE, quietly stand guard around the perimeter of the SUV. Sanborn relieves his bladder on an innocent sand dune. James and Eldridge are hanging out with the MERCENARY TEA LEADER. He’s bragging about his two high-value prisoners, appear in a DECK of MOST WANTED PLAYING CARDS.
(re: the EPW’s) Picked them up in Najaf. Nine of hearts... Jack of Clubs.
Same guys?
That’s them. James, mildly impressed, notices that Feisal is having an issue with the tire wrench.
Need a little help there? What’s the problem with the tire? Why the delay?  58
No good, boss. This wrench is too small.
Alright, solutions anyone?
I think there is another wrench in the back of the Humvee if you want to check.
Thanks, I’11 look. Feisal walks to the EOD HUMVEE.
How long are you guys out here?
I don’t know. Specialist, what do we got?
We've got...ah...seventeen more days.
But no one is counting, right. Feisal returns with a new wrench, when...
Contact left! Contact left!

head_text.subj: --THE MERCENARIES AND SOLDIERS ALL BEGIN SHOOTING TOWARDS
THEIR LEFT HAND SIDE, UNLEASHING A BARRAGE OF INDISCRIMIN
--ANOTHER BULLET ZIPS BY, NARROWLY MISSING ONE OF THE

text: Bedlam: as the firing continues on all sides, the mercena scramble for supplies and ammunition in their SUV, follow the commands of their leader who shouts “Jimmy get the go bags,” “Charlie, grab the Barrett”, “Chris take the fifty “into the ravine”, etc.  59 CHRIS leaps into the HUMVEE turret and sprays bullets in directions. The soldiers dash for cover into
a nearby ravine, and continue firing indiscriminately
Chris makes the big gun smoke. Spent brass spins red hot out of the barrel and large cal bullets pound the desert. But there is no enemy in sight.
(shouting) What are we shooting at?
(shouting back) I don’t know! suv In the confusion, the two hooded prisoners rise up and ru blindly into the desert.
Seeing that his valuable prisoners are escaping, the TEAM LEADER shouts:
The packages are moving!
They will not get far on foot.  60

Three bloody months hunting those fuckers. I’m out five hundred thousand quid! With that, the TEAM LEADER brazenly dashes into the open order to get an angle on the fleeing prisoners and as bul snap around him he shoots the prisoners in the back. Then he bolts to the ravine, very pleased with himself: MERCENARY TEAM LEADER (CONT’D) I forgot, it’s five hundred thousand DEAD OR ALIVE!
Chris in the turret of the Humvee keeps firing the machin gun in all directions.
As the shooting continues, the Mercenary Team Leader scrambles up one side of the ravine.

Jimmy, give me the Barrett. [referring to a .50 caliber tripod-mounted sniper rifle] The Mercenary Team Leader hoists this heavy gun to the ed of the ravine and looks down the scope. Jimmy crawls next to him with a spotting scope in hand.
Chris is still working the machine gun, expending hundred bullets a minute.
The Mercenary Leader says to Jimmy:
Chris is shooting wild. We have to conserve ammo.  61
(into radio) Hey Chris - can you hear me? Chill out on the fifty.
Chris ceases fire for a moment and takes his finger off t trigger. Silence while he keys his walkie.
(into walkie) Roger that. -- A bullet strikes him in the neck, killing him instantl
He shot Chris. The mercenary team leader deflates. He rests his chin on rifle. Everyone else in the ravine ceases firing as the futility their situation sinks in.
Scanning the barren landscape. Gravel and sun. No enemy, a living soul in sight. Then...a structure...a one-story building, in the far distance.
It must be coming from that building.
I can’t see anything.
Heat shimmers.  62 Then...on the roof of the building...slight movement. Possibly, it’s a MAN lying prone. Possibly, it’s two MEN.
Movement on the roof. The mercenary team leader concentrates his aim. He fires.
A pause while the bullet closes the gap - then SMASHES in the building’s side, tearing apart bricks and mortar. The figures on the roof, if they are men, have certainly unharmed.
Three meters higher.
I’ve got to adjust. He jostles the heavy sniper rifle forward a few inches.
Inside the building, an INSURGENT SNIPER team peers at th ridge-ravine complex where the mercenaries and soldiers h taken cover.
The wispy form of the two mercenaries lying on the ridge be faintly seen.
The sniper’s muzzle FLASHES.  63

The mercenary team leader hoists himself up into a low cr only to -- --take the bullet square in the chest --spinning him off the ridge -- face first into the ravine -- his back a pulped and bloody mess from the exit wound.
Jimmy jumps down from the ridge to check for a pulse.
He’s dead. Now the men plummet into a full-bore panic and everyone starts talking at once.
I’ll get on the Barret. Go, go.
No Sanborn don’t do that. Go, go. Stay low.
(into radio) ) Roger that, Alpha Nine. Go This is Alpha Nine. We’re in ahead. deep shit. We’re taking incoming fire.
Sanborn crawls to the Barrett, followed by James, who tak Jimmy's spotting scope. Effectively, our soldiers have replaced the first sniping team.
(into walkie) We are taking incoming fire. (MORE )
64 JIMMY (cont'd) I have two KIA. Correction three KIA. Can you get us some help?
Roger that Alpha Nine. Go ahead.
Our grid -- MDRF:5542973420. DISPATCH O.S. Alpha Nine, this is Big North Seven. You are going to have to sit tight. Off his despair:
Sanborn prepares to shoot at the men in the building.
(quietly) Breathe easy. I got movement at that house. 800 meters. By the window: you have a target
Got it. Sanborn squeezes the trigger. The muzzle flashes.
A bullet strikes the left side of the house. Another miss
(softly) A little left. Sanborn squeezes the trigger... only to hear the METALLIC CLICK of an empty chamber.
I’m out of ammo.  65
Huh?
I’m out of ammo.
(shouting over his shoulder) Eldridge! We need ammo.
Eldridge frantically searches a few nearby backpacks.
I need that ammo man!

I'm looking. Where is it? JAMES O.S. Check the dead guy. Eldridge flips over the body of the slain contractor. His chest is pulped. Nestled in the gore are several .50 magazines. Eldridge g them with shaky hands and passes them up to James.
James passes the ammo to Sanborn. He slams it into the receiver.
Same target.
Got it. Sanborn pulls the trigger. Click. ECU: Hand cycling the weapon. Finger pulling trigger. Bol catching, jammed.  66
It’s jammed. The blood is making it jam. Sanborn removes the clip and hands it back to James who h it back down to Eldridge in the ravine, instructing him:

Eldridge, you got to clean the blood off the bullets. The blood is making it jam. Eldridge takes the magazine and rubs the top bullet to no good effect, for the dust on his hands sticks to the bloo and the blood sticks to the bullet. He rubs harder, only making it dirtier. James peers down and realizes that Eldridge is lost.

Spit and rub, man. Spit on them. Eldridge tries to spit on the bullets. His mouth is too dry to produce salvia. He tries again. Nothing. James sees his escalating despair and slides down the rid coming next to Eldridge.

Use your camel (referring to the Camelback water canteen). James squeezes the nipple of Eldridge’s Camel and directs water to drip on the bullets. It sort of works. Sitting side by side now, they rub away the grime and pol the bullets to a bright shine.
You're doing good, man. You’re okay. I’m going to keep you safe. James takes the clean bullets and climbs back to the ridg telling Eldridge:
Scan your sectors.  67
Sanborn loads the clean bullets and fires.
One figure on the roof is hit. The other man crawls back out of sight.
Nice. You got him. Second one is out of range.
Scanning... Another FIGURE, lying on the desert floor.
Twenty meters to the right of the building. You got a target.
I got him.
Fire when ready.

Sanborn’s bullet strikes the ground a dozen feet in front the man, kicking up a harmless puff of dust. The man gets up and runs towards the building while firin his AK-47 back at Sanborn and James. His carbine’s muzzle flash, ineffective at this great range, sparkles in the bright day.
He’s moving to the building. Follow him. You got him?
Got him. Sanborn pulls the trigger.
68 Sanborn’s bullet strikes the fleeing man in the upper che blood spurting as the large round throws him dead to the ground.
You got him. He’s down. Good night. Thanks for playing.
The sniper in the building appears in the window.
The insurgent sniper team leans out the window and fires James and Sanborn.
The bullet snaps near James and Sanborn.
Window! Window!
Got it. Sanborn fires.
at Miss! Sanborn’s bullet strikes the building just below th window and the insurgent team withdraws inside.
He’s still there.  69 The insurgent, having run to the other side of the buildi now appears in the other window, the left window. James s his barrel.
Left window! Left window! Got him?
Got him. Sanborn turns his head away from the gun and makes an aud exhale to release tension: the sniper breath control technique. Then he fires a hit; the insurgent slumps in t window.
He’s down.
The roof of the tall building in the distance bobs in and of view; the scope dances at this range. James scans the area. Silence.
We mark the passage of time with dust devils spinning acr a horizon of lengthening shadows.

The sun lower in the sky. Around the pit, the fallen TEAM LEADER has been pushed to one side, and the living are hanging on to their sanity. Eldridge and the remaining contractors have exhausted the water supply. Eldridge is in a sentry position facing east, in the direction of the railroad tracks. The other two contracto are in sentry positions facing south and north. Sanborn and James are in EXACTLY the same position as whe left them, exposed to the elements. Desert heat and sand taken their toll on Sanborn especially.  70
The scope BLURS as Sanborn’s vision fails for a moment.
James notices Sanborn’s fatigue.

Eldridge, grab me the juice out of an MRE. Eldridge digs around the dead TEAM LEADER'S backpack and retrieves a packet of juice, which he passes to James. James inserts the straw into the juice pack. He hesitates, not sure if Sanborn will accept the gesture after all the hostility that’s passed between them... James brings the straw to Sanborn’s lips. At first, Sanborn keeps his attention on the rifle scope.
Drink. with some discomfort, Sanborn opens his sun-scorched lips sips.
Eldridge scans the horizon-- --a small HERD of GOATS amble along the railroad tracks. He rubs his eyes, looks again-- --Somewhere within the herd a flutter of fabric-- Eldridge stiffens.
Uh, Will.
Yeah.  71
At your six o'clock. Movement on the tracks.
Deal with it.
Uh, okay. Eldridge looks down his scope, unsure. James keeps his fo forward on the building.
Should I fire?

Your call. Eldridge shifts his weight onto his rifle. Another flutter of movement at the edge of the tracks. Eldridge pulls the trigger. Then he pulls it again. And again, emptying his magazine at the distant target. The goats scatter, revealing a lifeless BODY draped acros the tracks. Eldridge slumps, let’s go of his rifle.

Dusk. Shadows fall over James and Sanborn, both of whom remain lying in the exact same sniping position, although they are covered head to toe in sand. There’s no movement in the house. No movement on the far ridge. No sign of life anywhere beyond their encampment. It’s just them and the sky and the desert.
I think we're done.

72 INT CAMP VICTORY JAMES’ TRAILER NIGHT Play time: James and Sanborn square off, drunk, swaying, faced, fists clenched. When Sanborn nods, James punches h in the stomach. James smiles; he looks good. The unleashed aggression is a vitamin to him.
That’s what you get for hitting your team-leader, motherfucker. With difficulty, Sanborn straightens up and stumbles out the trailer.
Be right back. I gotta piss. James lurches towards Eldridge.
Owen, another round. That’s an order.
(imitating a young recruit) Yes, Sir, Sergeant James Sir. You're not very good with people are you -- but you’re a natural warrior.
You acquitted yourself well on the field of battle today, Specialist. They clink cups. Eldridge gulps his whiskey. James collapses in his chair. Eldridge sits down carefully.
I was scared.

Everyone is a coward about something. (beat) You did good.  73 As Sanborn loudly stumbles back into the room, he notices the door something a little odd under James’ bed: a box. odd because there is nothing else in the barren room besi Army-issue furniture, lights, and the whiskey they’ve bee drinking. Curious, Sanborn retrieves the box out and sets it ona makeshift coffee table to get a better look.
Just what do we have here? Will has possessions! I didn’t know you owned anything, Will.
Let’s see what you got. Sanborn pulls out a weathered snapshot of a baby boy.
What’s that?
That’s my son. He’s a real tough little bastard. Nothing like me.
You’re married?

Well, I had a girlfriend. She got pregnant and we got married and then we divorced. Or, I thought we divorced. She’s still in the house and she says we're still together. So I don’t know. What does that make her?
Dumb - for still being with your ass.
(hotly) She ain’t dumb. She’s just loyal, that’s all. (beat) What about you guys - what have you got?
My problem is the girl I like I can’t stop from talking about babies.  74
Give her your sperm, stud. Make babies!
Nah.
Go on, you chickenshit. Do it!
No, I know when I’m ready and I’m not ready for that yet. (looking around the box, finds a circuit board) And what do we have here?
(embarrassed) Components. Bomb parts. Signatures.
I see that. But what are they doing under your bed? James pulls out a circuit and gazes reverently at the mechanical design.

This one is from the UN building, flaming car. Dead man switch - boom! This guy was good. I like him. This one was from our first call together. This box is full of stuff that almost killed me. Eldridge rummages through the box and finds a gold ring hanging from a cheap chain. He dangles the ring in front of James.
What’s this one from, Will?
That’s my wedding ring. Like I said, stuff that almost killed me. (beat) I think it’s interesting to hold something in your hands that could have killed any one of us.  75
(looking at the circuit board) It’s a piece of junk from Radio Shack. Eldridge, ever unsure, allies with James.
It’s interesting.

I agree. I think it’s I think that punch was harder interesting, too. than I hit you. Therefore, I owe you a punch. So get up motherfucker. James leaps up, pleased to end the conversation. Sanborn follows, clapping his hands -- cruising for a bruising.
Hold on, we need some rules. No face shots.

(laughing) There’s gonna be a face shot. Eldridge picks up a magic marker and tells James to take his shirt. Then he draws a bulls-eye on James’ bared stomach. And as he does, he notices knotty scar tissue.
What happened?
My mother dropped me at birth.

Looks like frag scars. Let it go, Eldridge. James smiles, raises his arms, exposing his midsection to Sanborn. Sanborn winds up for a powerful blow. He leans back, then launches a gut punch that knocks James to the floor. James lies there in a heap, laughing.  76 When he gets up, he’s laughing so hard that gleeful tears down his face.
You like that?

That all you got? Now Sanborn raises his arms, bracing for the blow. James feints a right cross, fakes a jab, then grabs Sanbo by the neck and unleashes a brutal uppercut to the solar plexus. Sanborn collapses, moaning in pain.
(laughing) That’s got to hurt.
You alright?
Yeah.

Get up, bitch. James extends his hand to help Sanborn off the floor. But when Sanborn reaches for help, James rushes him wildl like a football tackle, knocking him back to the floor, a in a sudden fit of aggression, he then jumps on Sanborn’s chest, pins his arms with his knees and clasps his throat
What have you got now?
Get off me!
Come on, what have you got.

Get off of me you freak!! Sanborn tries to buck James off but he can’t dislodge the former Ranger. Sanborn redoubles his efforts, throwing his weight this w and that. Still, James remains on top -- his face twisted with a macho snarl.  77

We got a wild one here!! Sanborn bucks harder. But instead of knocking James loose his kicking and struggling to get free spurs James to eve deeper levels of male weirdness. And as Sanborn kicks and bucks underneath him, James pumps his hand like a cowboy rodeo, crying out:
I'm riding him! That's right!! He's a wild one and I’m riding him!!
Now Sanborn reaches for his boot knife. ECU: knife blade snapping open Sanborn jams the blade against James’ throat and their ey lock. James smiles like a child. He pats Sanborn’s head and lau
I’m just kidding motherfucker!! Shit!!! At last, Sanborn is released. James pats him on the chest
You're alright, Sanborn. (to Eldridge) Owen, get this guy another drink.
Sanborn, too drunk to stand, is being guided across the barracks square by Eldridge and James. When they come to Eldridge’s trailer, James shoulders Sanborn by himself an Eldridge goes inside.
Later. It’s not easy for James to carry Sanborn alone and Sanbor nearly slips to the ground.

You need to go on a diet.  78 They walk a little farther to Sanborn’s trailer, passing SOLDIER who looks at them curiously. Drinking is not allo on US bases in Iraq. James brushes aside the officious lo saying “he hurt his knee” and guides Sanborn up a set of stairs into Sanborn’s trailer. INT. SANBORN’S TRAILER James eases Sanborn onto a cot and heads for the door.
Get some rest. Sanborn mumbles drunkenly:
Hey James, do you think I have what it takes to put on the suit?

(beat) Hell no. (Beat) Good night, boy. INT JAMES’ TRAILER LATER THAT NIGHT James stumbles inside, flops on the bed, and takes anothe swig of whiskey. He lies there and stares at his bomb helmet, which is sit on a desk adjacent to his cot. He looks at the helmet... and reaches for it. Then he brings the helmet over his head and adjusts the straps and unlocks the glass protective masks, so that it snaps down over his face and his entire head is sheathed the protective metal.
A man encased in his armor. He leans back in the bed and we HEAR the rasp of James BREATHING. ..daydreaming...as he re-experiences the feeli a bomb in his hands, the morbid thrill.

head_text.subj: EXT/INT HUMVEE CAMP VICTORY PARKING LOT

text: A massive sandstorm is underway. Howling winds disperse r sand over the entire base, giving it an otherworldly, alm Martian aspect. Throngs of men and their vehicles fight t brutal weather.
Days Left in Bravo Company’s Rotation: 16 Lt. Col. Cambridge comes out of the gloom, approaches the vehicles window, and knocks.
Mind if I ride along? I’m sick of sitting behind a desk all the time. James shoots Eldridge a look. Eldridge shrugs.

It’s a privilege. (as Cambridge gets in) ) I don’t mean to insult your intelligence, Sir, but if the shit hits the fan please don’t fire out the Humvee, the rounds will just bounce around and someone might get shot. I don’t like getting shot.
Understood, Sergeant.

head_text.subj: EXT. ABU GHRAIB CENTER BOMBED OUT BUILDING DAY

text: A partially destroyed building fills the screen. A mess o bricks and rebar. Wind swirls sand up into the air.

DAYS LEFT IN BRAVO COMPANY’S ROTATION: 16 Nearby, an OLD IRAQI MAN with a DONKEY drawn cart is unloading new bricks to repair the building. Farther up the road, a good distance from the building, a two parked Humvees. Nearby, James and his team are talkin a small cluster of SOLDIERS. Eldridge gives Cambridge the drill:  80
This is a pretty standard mission. We're just here to pick up some ordnance. Sergeant James is going to go see what the deal is. Hopefully, we’re gone in a couple of minutes
Guys, we got to gear up.
For what?
Security hasn’t gone in. Let’s just go in quiet, radios off.
Glad you came.
Stay safe.

James, Sanborn and Eldridge enter a landing. The floor is very wet. They cross it, and come to a room that has been severely damaged by a bomb, with rubble everywhere and exposed electrical wires dangling from the ceiling, and busted pipes gushing water. A tea pot sits on a STOVE, steaming hot, and a plate on the table has bread on it.

They gingerly investigate a large cavernous room with lea pipes dripping water onto an oil-slicked floor. We HEAR t breathing, the water DROPLETS falling. Moving tactically, covering all sides of their approach, they press deeper i the building down
A dark corridor which the insurgents have strewn with gla as an early-warning system. Advancing slowly, glass CRUNC underfoot, they pass through this corridor into  81
A classroom lined with student’s desks and chairs, beyond which lies another room. James and Sanborn spin quietly i this room, rifles raised, while Eldridge hangs back to co the corridor.

They find themselves in a recently used living area. A te cooking on a bunsen burner hisses steam. Mattresses and bedding line the walls of the room. The walls are decorat with Jihadist slogans, and a video camera for making recruiting videos has pride of place on a tripod in the center of the room. Sanborn checks under the mattresses for hidden explosives finds none, and exchanges a worried look with James. Moving as one unit they spin into the next room.
It’s empty, another forboding large space strewn with rub and garbage. They pass through this area and push open a to --

Santa’s bomb making factory. In contrast to the spare spaces they’ve just passed throu this room is overflowing with the tools of a an insurgenc that uses bombs as its primary weapon: electronics and explosives of all kinds are everywhere: artillery shells, boxes of batteries, plastic explosives, military manuals, rockets, grenades, stacks of dynamite, tools, magnifying glasses, and soldering guns. Though a few of these munitions bear the stamps of foreig militaries, most bear insignias in English. It is, ironically, a cache of armaments that formerly belonged t the American military. The men weave through the piles of explosives, slowly checking every space where a human could possibly be hidi At last they’re satisfied:  82
Clear! Eldridge draws near to one desk where a cigarette burns i ashtray.
This cigarette is still smoking!
This is all our shit. Motherfucking gold mine. Watch out for trips.

In the back half of the room, a plastic curtain hangs ove work table, forming a make-shift sterile room. Smelling the copper odor of blood and death emanating fro behind that curtain, James pushes the plastic to one side He draws near to a table, where he sees the DEAD BODY of YOUNG BOY wearing pants but no shirt. Flies buzz over his bloody bare chest.

I got something. Sanborn and Eldridge come beside him, and approach the bo cautiously. The dead young man’s chest has been cut open. An artiller shell is shoved inside the cavity where the heart used to beat. Wires protrude from the shell. James shakes his head no as Sanborn moves closer to the b and inspects the wiring in the chest. The boy’s FACE, half in shadow, is so disfigured by bruis that it’s hard to identify. But it might be someone famil to James.
I know this kid. His name is Beckham. He sells DVDs. Sanborn ignores that and turns to Eldridge.
You ever see a body bomb before?  83 Eldridge shakes his head, pulling his neck scarf up over nose.
This is disgusting, let’s get out of here.
Eldridge, grab all the C4 and det cord you can get your hands on. Let’s get the rest of it out of here and just blow it in place.
Roger that. Sanborn and Eldridge leave James alone with the body. He stares at the boy.
Cambridge, with limited Iraqi language skills, is trying speak to a MAN piling rocks in the back of his donkey car
What are you doing? Moving the rocks? The Iraqi peasant replies in Arabic, motioning to the roc and his cart.
That’s very nice. It’s a little unsafe today. So maybe - I don’t know - I’m thinking maybe we should move.
James steps away.
Sanborn and Eldridge meet up outside.
You okay?  84
Yeah. You?

head_text.subj: INT BOMBED OUT BUILDING MOMENTS LATER

text: James turns away from the body. Thinks. Eldridge arrives with the C4. The look on James’ face concerns him.
You alright man?

Yeah, no one in or out. Eldridge nods. Makes a hasty exit. James pulls C4 blocks from his pack and arranges them aro the body. He plugs a blasting cap into the C4. In doing s finds himself drawn to the dead boy’s eyes, which seem somehow to stare directly at him. James tries to keep his feelings in check and his mind on task by arranging the charges and preparing the detonatio But he can’t. The war has finally reached him.
(into walkie) Cancel the det. In one fluid motion James removes the charges and takes o his helmet. He closes the boy’s eyes. And slams his fists on the table.
Sanborn and Eldridge grab water by the Humvee.
What the fuck is he doing?
I don’t know.  85
Now there are a few IRAQI MEN gathered near the donkey ca Cambridge is doing his best to communicate.
Hello, how are you?
Where are you from?
New York. The Big Apple.
I’m from Iraq.
I love it here. This is a beautiful place. But today, it’s not too safe here, so I think we need to move. Please.

James carefully checks the boy’s body for trip wires, the proceeds the snip the wires which were sown into the boy’ stomach. One by one, he cuts them. He inserts his hands into the boy’s abdomen and removes t artillery shell bomb that had been diabolically placed th He wipes his face, smearing blood, then covers the body i white cloth.
(into walkie) I’m coming down. The boy’s blood seeps through the cloth and stains it red
James carries the boy’s body down the narrow corridor. Th head and feet bump the sides.  86

James brings the body out carries it to a blue and white pickup TRUCK emblazoned with the logo of the Iraqi Nation Police pulls up to their position. A pair of POLICEMEN get out and after a few words with Ja they load the body.
James watches the police truck drive away. He then moves the Humvee, motioning for Cambridge to load up.
Sanborn and Eldridge sit across from each other, watching James.
.»+-So you think it was that little base rat?
No I don’t.
You positive?
Sure. I don’t know. They all look the same, right?
I don’t know. Will seemed sure. But that was weird.
Very weird.
Cambridge, losing patience with what is now a small crowd Iraqis, motions with his M4.

Please, just move. Please. Ishmee (pronouncing the Arabic incorrectly).  87 The crowd slowly disperses, amid grumbling and cursing. Cambridge waves patronizingly at them as they go, saying “thank you, bye-bye,” etc. He doesn’t notice that one of older men has left on the ground a_white rice bag.
Simultaneously, the conversation in the Humvee continues:
But then Will's pretty weird. He keeps bomb parts under his bed.
I bet you he doesn’t keep any of these parts under his bed. James cracks the door of the Humvee, leans inside, sees Cambridge -

(shouting to Cambridge) Let's go! Through the HUMVEE windshield: Cambridge, now pleased tha the crowd has gone, waves good-bye to the entire neighborhood, and, hearing James, steps towards the Humve passing the white rice bag, which suddenly -- --explodes in a A SICKENING BLAST --obliterating Cambridge --sending his head crashing into the HUMVEE, along with a could of debris which instantly blackens the windshield a blots out the sun and our view of everything -

CRIES of “IED!” “IED” as our three soldiers stumble out o the vehicle into the rancid air, while other soldiers, dashing to the scene from all sides, scramble to restore order and shout “it’s the commander” “watch your six”, et We follow Eldridge, stunned, as he walks into the afterma and finds a smoking helmet on the ground. He picks it up. Its nylon cover is burning; the inside is charred.  88 Eldridge looks down and sees body parts and bits of unifo strewn on the ground.
Where’s Cambridge? Cambridge! Come on, we got to go! (beat) Doc? James rushes to Eldridge’s side.
He’s dead.
I just saw him! He was walking right here! James pulls Eldridge into a bear hug. Eldridge sobs.
He’s dead. He’s dead. (beat) But you’re alright, buddy. You're alright.
As the sun sets behind him, James leans against a power p and dials a SATELLITE PHONE. He hangs up. Dials again.
In a modest mid-Western kitchen, the phone rings. A young WOMAN holding a BABY rushes to get it.
Hello? (beat) Will? Hello? Silence on the other end of the line.
James hangs up and shoves the phone back in his pocket.  89

head_text.subj: EXT CAMP VICTORY MESS TENT MORNING

text: James, smoking, twitchy, watching something... the OLDER IRAQI MAN who sells DVDs at Beckham’s usual table. Althou Beckham is not there, the man organizes his DVDs, busines usual. James stalks up to him.
Hey, let me ask you a question, what happened to the little kid that used to work here? The man shakes his head.
Sorry man, no English.
No English? Now you don’t speak English. The little kid? Beckham is his name. He sells DVDs.
DVD? One DVD five dollars. James turns to a nearby INFANTRY GUARD.
Excuse me, soldier, are you in charge of this area?
What’s up?
That guy over there could be an insurgent. (referring to the DVD merchant) How do we know he’s not giving intel to his buddies, telling them where to drop mortars?
I think he’s just selling DVDs.
He’s a security risk. You should get rid of him.
He’s just selling DVDs. All the merchants are cleared. (MORE )
159 90 GUARD (cont'd) I couldn't do anything to him without the say-so from my C.O. James, agitated, seeing that he has no hope of prevailing turns away and trudges back into Camp Victory’s maze.

head_text.subj: EXT. CAMP VICTORY MESS TENT HOURS LATER

text: It’s the end of the day and the DVD seller packs up his w to close shop. James, in sunglasses, sweatshirt covering army fatigues, watches him do this, and then follows the to his truck. As the man starts the engine, James jumps i the passenger side and threatens with his pistol.
Does this change anything? Speak English now, don’t you? Drive!
The truck passes through a middle-class Baghdad neighborh and comes to a stop at a house surrounded by an 8-foot hi concrete wall.
This is the house? Beckham’s house? The driver nods, sort of.
Wait here.

James gets out and jogs to the house. He tries the front gate, sees that it is locked, and while he does the car drives off. If he cares, he doesn’t show it. James scales the wall an drops inside the front courtyard.
A modest courtyard. Light comes from one window in the ho the rest is dark. Crickets. Inside, a TV is playing. Jame tries the front door. It opens.  91
In a dark hallway. Murmuring of a television. James moves towards the noise.
James comes to an antechamber. Behind it is a very low st archway. He goes through the archway, where -
A MAN -- call him KALIM -- older, fifties, dressed in Wes fashion, is busy at the sink, washing dishes. James walks gun raised. Kalim drops a dish. James puts his fingers to lips, shhhh.
Do you speak English?
English, French, Arabic.
(quietly) Good. Open your vest. Stay there. Tell me what you know about Beckham.
For whom?
Beckham. The 12-year old boy, the body bomb.
Beckham? I don’t know. But please sit down. I am professor Kalim, this is my home. You are a guest. Please sit down.
I’m a guest...I’m just looking for the people responsible.

You are CIA, no? I am very pleased to have CIA in my home. Please, sit.  92 As his certainty slips away, James hears rustling and spi to see -- a WOMAN, older, matronly, carrying a tea tray. She see James, his gun, and starts cursing him in Arab, appalled an armed American would come to her house. James steps back. Her cursing grows fiercer. She raises h tea tray.

Be careful! The gun can go off. Undaunted, she throws the tray at James. He twists to avo it, takes a few steps to the door, and ends up HITTING hi HEAD badly on the concrete archway as he runs out of the house.

James is shaken. He looks around and down the street. He runs...and runs...Blood runs from the wound on his head a navigates the busy Iraqi neighborhood at night, running d streets teeming with SHOPPERS who stare at him ominously, dodging traffic, moving past OLD MEN smoking at a CAFE wh note his panic, by a BUTCHER SHOP where an entire COW CAR is being unloaded, and on and on... we stay with his eyes Off the a screeching car as James dashes across a street,
James, hands held high over his head, walks up to one of camp's check-points, shouting:
USA Friendly coming in! Powerful flood lights switch on, blinding him. Then the screaming of hyped up guards:
Stop, get the fuck down. On Don’t fucking move! your knees!
Stop! On your knees, on your knees!!  93 James sinks to his knees.
Open your fucking jacket! Cover James unzips his sweatshirt and declares:
I have a weapon! A guard armed with a shotgun charges out of the glare and kicks James to the ground, pinning his knee into his back
Searching! The guard finds James’ pistol. He shouts:
Like I said. (beat) Do you Gun!! Weapon’s clear!! want to look at my I.D.?
What are you doing out here?
(gasping) I was at a whore house.
(thinking it over) Okay, if I let you in, will you tell me where it is exactly?
James steps into his trailer. His walkie, sitting on a de CRACKLES to life.
(over walkie) I repeat, do you copy? Do you have your ears on? James?
(into walkie) Yeah, this is James. What’s up?  94
