In a bustling parking lot, aglow with headlights from Hum and troop carries, we find James running towards one Humv which he jumps into. Sanborn is at the wheel and not amus
We have a tanker explosion in the Green Zone. We have to do a post- blast assessment, see if it was a suicide bomber and if so how he pulled it off. (beat) So where did you say you were again?
I didn’t, Sergeant. Let’s go.
What happened to your head, James? James gives no reply. He turns to Eldridge.
Ready? Game face buddy. As the Humvee rolls out of the base,
USA Friendlies coming in!

A helicopter spotlight illuminates a Hieronymus Bosch nightmare of tangled limbs and body parts. Then fires, sm and the cries of wailing grievers and wounded carried on stretchers, ambulances, police, fire trucks...the ghastly frantic aftermath of a major detonation. Their combat flashlights send piercing white beams into t grim spectacle, while in the distance a huge fire, a GLOW RED INFERNO at the end of the block, lights what we now s is a blast radius that extends for a nearly a mile. Moving towards the glowing fire, past ten foot high flame and the remains of houses pulverized to concrete and glas rubble piles, past screaming women and more bloody wounde being carried away by IRAQI POLICE...  95 they pause to try and help Iraqi police save a man pinned under a car. He’s dragged away like a rag doll. They press on towards the inferno and stop when they noti hunk of metal.
Oil tanker?
Yup. Pretty long flight. Moving ahead, the men split up, navigating different path through this hectic apocalypse:

A Bhurka-clad WOMAN appears out of the distant flames and haze, looking disoriented, in apparent shock. Behind her blazing car. On the ground beside the car lies a single black loafer. Eldridge sees the lone shoe and is at a loss to process i significance. Another mind-numbing, soul-numbing casualty of war.

At a gigantic rubble pile, Sanborn reaches down to remove chunks of stone covering a BODY. The stone slides away but another falls in its place. Sanborn looks down, sees a second man, or what’s left of man: head and torso but no legs -- just stumps, twitching Around him, GRIEVING FAMILIES pick through the dead and d with IRAQI MEDICS.
Drawing near to the inferno, he moves past burning palm t which erupt into a fountain of embers. And comes at last to the burning steel carcase of...  96

an OIL TANKER. From what's left of the twisted metal sub-frame flames tw feet high scorch the night, like the maw of hell on earth James stares, transfixed by the burning...the imprint of insurgent’s plan. His face hardens now in a way we haven’t seen before, and the fire flickers on his features he seems lost in a priv war of his own. The insurgents are out there somewhere. Ahab and the Whale.

Sanborn and Eldridge look helplessly at a girl who is tra on the landing of a half-destroyed building. She cries fo her father. Behind them, several platoons of U.S. SOLDIERS and IRAQI POLICE arrive to secure the boundaries of the blast zone.
James approaches a LEMON GROVE which lies just beyond the fire’s reach. As Sanborn and Eldridge walk up behind him, James touches UNBLEMISHED LEMON nestled among the thorns.
This is the edge of the blast radius. Sanborn comes into view. James nods to him, then stares i the distance, a man possessed.
So where's our trigger man?
Burnt up in the flames. Suicide bomber. You'll never find a body.  97

But what if there was no body. What if it was a remote det? (beat) A really good bad guy hides out in the dark, right? This is a perfect vantage point outside the blast radius to set back and watch us --
You want to go out there?
Yes I do.
I could stand to get in some trouble. Sanborn looks at James and looks at the bandage on his he
No, man, this is bullshit. You got --what?-- three infantry platoons here whose job it is to go haji hunting. That’s not our job.

You don’t say ‘No’ to me, Sergeant. I say ‘No’ to you. You know there are guys watching us right now. (on the move) We're going. James glowers at Sanborn and Eldridge and moves deeper in an unlit field behind the lemon grove. Eldridge shoots Sanborn a sympathetic glance and follows James. Sanborn watches them recede into the darkness. Then he ru after his team.

They move across the dark field, three abreast into the enveloping night. We gradually lose sight of them in BLACKNESS. Seeing noth we HEAR, however, their BREATHING, and gravel CRUNCHING underfoot.  98 After a long moment of no visibility...they’re faintly visible again in dim florescent light and we see:

A shadowy parking lot filled with marooned cars, beyond w lies a neighborhood of one-story homes and narrow alleys. Amid the cars, the men come across the bullet-shaped hull an intact oil tanker. They crouch beside it, whispering:
We know where the oil tanker came from.
It’s the same kind.

We're close. These alleys are probably set up in a grid. We’re going to split up to flush them out. Sanborn take the first alley. Eldridge take two. I got three. Rally point at your intersection. Ready? Move!
Wait? Rally point? When? But James has already dashed into the third alley.
Eldridge, walking slowly, not sure he likes being alone.
James runs confidently, sees a few kids in a doorway and tells them to scoot.
Sanborn runs to make up for being the last to leave.  99
Eldridge peers into an abandoned house. He thinks he hear something. Spins. It’s nothing.
Sanborn slows. Catches his breath when suddenly -- --BLAM, BLAM, BLAM - the staccato of GUNFIRE slaps off th concrete-- Sanborn dashes full speed back to the alley’s opening.
James turns, runs hard back into--
--the first intersection, where he sees Sanborn and shout
You got contact?!
Who is it?! What’s going on?
What have you got?!
It's Eldridge!!
They come to Eldridge’s alley where they see that a body on the ground. They run to it.
Man down!!
Eldridge!!  100 As they draw close they see not Eldridge but the BODY of Iraqi insurgent, dead from gunshot wounds.
It’s not him.
He’s gone?! A moment of decision.
That way is towards the tanker, troops. They run down the alley into a maze of narrow streets and dimly lit corridors.
Turning a corner, they catch a fleeting glimpse of Eldrid being dragged away by TWO INSURGENTS. Before they can fire, the men are gone.
They run to this corner and prepare to spin around it and shoot. James hands Sanborn his flashlight.
Hit ‘em with both lights. One, two, three!
They spin around the corner and flash light revealing NOT but an empty street.
They sprint to the next block, and again see Eldridge bei dragged.

One, two, three.  101 Again, they aim and spin: Sanborn shines the light - beam Eldridge and the two insurgents -- and James FIRES two sh bursts from his M4. The two insurgents collapse. But Eldridge also goes down. Running up, James and Sanborn see the insurgents are motionless, shot clean. One bullet, however, has gone astray into Eldridge’s leg he’s bleeding profusely.
Eldridge you okay?
I’m hit! As James and Sanborn apply first aide:
You hit him in the leg!
(panting) Am I dead?
No, you're alright.
You're fine. Eldridge looks to Sanborn for confirmation that wound is indeed not mortal.
Am I dead? Am I dead? Am I dead? As Sanborn and James yank Eldridge off the ground, he scr in pain.

head_text.subj: INT CAMP VICTORY SHOWER STALLS LATER THAT NIGHT

text: James trudges into an empty bathroom and looks at himself the mirror. Sees the faraway expression of a man lost to war.  102 His shirt is crimson with Eldridge’s blood. He steps inside a shower stall, still dressed in full bat rattle, and turns on the hot faucet. The water streams over him...and he lets go, punching the wall, thrashing his arms, then sinking down sobbing, brok as his uniform soaks through and the reddish pink water swirls down the drain.

head_text.subj: EXT CAMP VICTORY HEAD SHED MORNING

text: Looking fine and wearing a fresh clean uniform, James str purposely out of the head shed toward a waiting Humvee in parking lot. He sees on the other side of the parking lot... none othe than Beckham, who happily shouts to him:

Hey, what’s up man? Hey Boomala, Boomala, wanna buys some DVDs, play some soccer! James stops. He stares. What can he say? The boy is fine. His jihad was pointless. Insane. Unable to face the kid and unwilling to explain, James tu away and stiffly gets into the Humvee. The Humvee roars to life and drives away. Beckham watches it go, hurt, confused. Prelap: the ROTAR WASH of a helicopter preparing to fly.
Two SOLDIERS load Eldridge, strapped to a stretcher, onto transport helicopter. Sanborn and James run across the helipad to wish him good bye.
How you doing? Doc says you’ll be okay.  103
My femur is shattered in nine places. He said I'll be walking in six months if, I’m lucky.
Six ain’t bad.
Not bad? It fucking sucks man. Eldridge is jostled as he gets put down; he cries out in pain.
(angrily) You see that! That’s what happens when you shoot somebody, you motherfucker.
I’m sorry. Sorry.

You're sorry? Fuck you, Will. Really fuck you. Thanks for saving my life but we didn’t have to go out looking for trouble so you could get your adrenaline fix, you fucking war mongerer. James is crestfallen. A U.S. MEDIVAC CREW MEMBER looks at Sanborn and gives a h signal to wrap it up: time to go.
(to Sanborn) Take care of yourself, Owen.

(grabbing Eldridge’s hand) Get home safe. See you on the other side. As the helicopter door slams closed, Eldridge shouts “let get out of this desert.” James and Sanborn step back from the rotor wash. James turns to say something to Sanborn. But he’s already walking away.  104
(shouting) Don’t move! If you keep walking, we will shoot you!

head_text.subj: EXT BAGHDAD STREET CHECKPOINT LATE AFTERNOON

text: A young SERGEANT at a checkpoint raises his M4 and shouts nervously at a bewildered Iragi MAN in a BLACK SUIT. The man’s hands are raised. He’s standing alone in the middle a square which has been cleared of all other pedestrians, which is flanked by US ARMY soldiers and a TRANSLATOR disguising his identity by wearing a black ski mask.
Don’t move! Keep that translator back!
But the bomb was forced on him.
Don’t move. Stay still. If you keep walking we will shoot you. SHOUTING IN ARABIC as the translator conveys this command
DAYS LEFT IN BRAVO COMPANY’S ROTATION: 2 James wearing his bomb suit, approaches the scene, while Sanborn follows close behind him in the Humvee.
Keep that translator back. One of the soldiers grabs the translator, while others, seeing James, shout “give him room,” “let him through,” e
(to the soldier) But the bomb was forced on him. Against his will. He is not a bad man! James and the Sergeant huddle.  105
He came walking up to our checkpoint, said he had a bomb strapped to him. He was sorry. He didn’t want it to go off. Then he started begging us to take it off him.
(to James) Help this man. He’s not a bad man.
Not a bad man? He’s got a bomb strapped to him. (to James) This is a trap. He wants to draw us close.

(to translator) Tell him to open his shirt, slowly. I need to see what’s inside. The translator SHOUTS in Arabic. The MAN unbuttons his jacket, revealing... Clamped to his chest is a metal cage, locked with padlock and loaded with blocks of C4 wrapped in nails.

(to the soldier) I'd need a seventy five meter perimeter. (to translator) Tell him to get on his knees and touch the sky. Get down! The translator SHOUTS. The man in the BLACK SUIT, gripped with despair, drops to his knees and raises his hands.
Can we just shoot him? As James considers that option when --
NO. He's not a bad man. He has a family. The bomb was forced on him. He is asking for help. Only help.  106
(to translator) I want you to get back. I got it. Sanborn pulls James aside for a private moment and pleads with him to be careful:

We've had our differences. Eldridge. It happened. That’s water under the bridge. But this -- this is suicide. James considers. Sanborn’s right, of course. But he can’t help himself. Like a moth to a flame, this is what he doe
That's why it’s called a suicide bomb, right? Sanborn reluctantly seals James in the helmet. They bang fists.

James grabs a nearby soldier’s walkie, then starts the wa downrange. Soldiers moving back to their perimeter... PEDESTRIANS gathering for a look. Soldiers scattering the quickly. Black Suit smiles thinly as James nears. James nods at hi The man nods, frightened.
Inshalla. Inshalla.
Put your hands up!
He says he has a family, James kneels down to get a closer look at the bomb strapp to the man’s belly. He takes out his 9mm and puts it on t guy's forehead. Cocks the trigger.
Look, it would be a lot easier for me to disarm this if I just shoot you. Do you understand?  107 BLACK SUIT replies in Arabic.
(into walkie) What is he saying?
(over walkie) He says, I don’t wish to die. I have a family. Please take this off me.
James holds his walkie up for the man to hear the transla
(headset) Tell him to put his hands behind his head or I will be very happy to shoot him. Translator conveys this to BLACK SUIT in Arabic. BLACK SU starts yelling in Arabic. Forehead wet with sweat.
(over walkie) He says, please hurry he has a family.

(to translator) Look, it’s not what I said. Tell him to put his hands behind his head or I will shoot him. James holds the walkie up to the man’s ear, “listen,” “do understand?” Now James sinks to his knees and examines the bomb, all t while keeping his pistol on the man’s head. There is a FOREST OF WIRES. He pushes them aside, revealing a cheap Casio digital WATCH, which is counting down from five minutes.  108
(headset) Sanborn, we got a timer. We got a lot of wires. I need a little help on this.
(over headset) Roger that, what do you need? James feels around the bomb. It’s strapped to the BLACK S man with heavy gauge metal. The man shakes.
(headset) Bolt cutters. But you got two minutes to get down here.
(over walkie) Roger that. I'll be there in thirty seconds.
Sanborn is already running towards the truck when he hear James.
James presses the man’s head to comfort him.
(to man) I know. Its’ okay. You’re alright. The Casio watch is at 4:30.
Sanborn runs hard with the bolt cutters.
Sanborn hands James the cutters. The man is crying. Sanborn sees the Casio. It reads 4:00  109
You weren't kidding.
Nope. James works the cutter blade. ECU: Bolt Cutter. It SCRAPES futilely against the metal.
(sotto) What is this made out of?
Case hardened steel. James doubles his effort. ECU: Bolt Cutter. The blade bites the steel, but it doesn give. James squeezes with all his might.
What’s our time?
Two minutes.
We'd need torch to get this off.
We don’t have one of those in the truck. He’s a dead man. ECU: Casio Watch 1:46.

Hold on let me think. We got this. I can handle it. I’m going to look at the back. Sanborn nods. His hand is starting to shake. James goes behind the man, and rips open the back of his shirt, revealing the back of the bomb. Here too it is a welded band, but the metal looks thinner James works it with the cutter. ECU: Casio Watch 1:30.  110
We don’t have enough time, Sanborn. We don’t have enough time. I have to get these bolts off.
We at a minute and a half, we got to get out of here.
I'll handle this. Go.
Look, Will, come on --
Go.
Fuck him, Come on, man. James --
Sanborn you have forty five seconds. YOU HAVE FORTY FIVE
He’s a dead man, Will!
Go! Sanborn runs uprange.
(shouting to soldiers)

The soldiers turn and run. James strains to clip the metal bar of the lock, putting of his weight into the effort. Finally, the blades slices ECU: broken lock falls to the ground. James sees that he has four more locks more to cut. The t is ticking down to 20 seconds. James brings himself face-to-face with the man he can’t s  111
I can’t There’s too many locks. I can’t do it. I can’t get it off. I’m sorry.
(in Arabic) Please, please, please--
I’m sorry. You hear me? I’m sorry?
(in Arabic) Help me. Help me! James drops the bolt cutter, kneels down in front of the and shakes his head. That’s it. The man understands James’ gesture. He reaches forward, grabbing James’ suit.
(in Arabic) No! No! Please James brushes his hand away.
I’m sorry. James turns his back to the man and runs for cover. --James running, arms akimbo --The Black Suit man stands up and cries out to ALLAH!

-- He explodes and a hailstorm of particulate matter come flying at 22,000 feet per second straight at us -- chunks of molten metal hit James, knocking him to the ground --Sanborn, diving to keep the translator behind a barrier grazed by shrapnel.  112

James’ white face; blood seeps from his nose. Then as if overcoming great resistance his heart turns over with a l beating. And as Sanborn recovers and shouts orders, “everybody out” in the background, James opens his eyes t the sky. A KITE flutters overhead.
The Humvee chugs through a crowded neighborhood. Traffic thickening. Shadows against a dimming sky.
James drives. Sanborn is in the passenger seat covered in grime and dust.
You alright?
No man. I hate this place James passes Sanborn some Gatorade.
Have a hit. Sanborn drinks, grateful, and puts the Gatorade down. The looks at James.
I’m not ready to die, James.
You're not going to die out here, bro. Sanborn shakes his head. Unconsciously, his fingers touch neck, finding the exposed area above the collar of his bo armor.
Another two inches. Shrapnel goes zing -- slices my throat. (MORE )
113 SANBORN (cont'd) I bleed out like a pig in the sand. Nobody will give a shit. I mean my parents, they care, but they don’t count. Who else? (beat) I don’t even have a son.
You're going to have plenty of time for that.
No man, I’m done. (beat) I want a son. I want a little boy, Will. A long beat.
I mean, how do you do it? Take the risk?
I don’t know. I guess I don’t think about it.
But you know what I’m talking about, right? Every time we go out, you throw the dice. You recognize that, right?
Yeah. I do. But I don’t know why. Do you know why -- I am the way I am? Sanborn thinks on this. After a beat -
No I don’t. They exchange a long look. Brothers at last.
A gang of laughing KIDS throw rocks at the armored Humvee

head_text.subj: INT KNOXVILLE, TENNESSEE SUPERMARKET MONTHS LATER

text: We're walking with James down a wide, polished aisle, pas shelves of frozen treats glistening behind reflective gla in the shiny and perfectly sterile cathedral to consumeri otherwise known as a supermarket. James looks different here, awkward, less sure of himself With his hair grown-in and his dreamy expression, he coul just another suburban softy pushing a shopping cart. He’s home but this is clearly not where he lives. A beautiful young WOMAN approaches him from the other end the aisle. She too is pushing a shopping cart and in it i small BOY. She smiles at James and says:
Honey, will you grab some cereal and I'll meet you at the checkout. CONNIE JAMES smiles again and pats her husband on the shoulder. As she walks away, he mumbles:
Where’s the cereal? But she’s already out of ear shot.

James stares at the rows and rows of cereal boxes, a medl of different brands all containing the same sugar and coloring and starch. He looks this way and that. Thrown by the abundant choices after the starkness of Baghdad, he can’t decide which brand is his. He reaches for a box, then pulls back, still unsure of himself. Giving up, he picks a box at random and tosses it into th cart.  115

head_text.subj: EXT KNOXVILLE JAMES HOUSE FRONT YARD LATE AFTERNOON SOME

text: Rain water. Falling leaves. James is cleaning out the gut working under an overcast sky.

head_text.subj: INT KNOXVILLE JAMES HOUSE LIVING ROOM EVENING

text: James zones out in front of a snowy TV; the glow plays on face.
Domesticity. Connie peels a pile of carrots. James washes mushrooms in the sink. He tries to clean them individually but they crumble in h hands.

Some guy drove his truck into a middle of an Iraqi market. He starts passing out free candies. All the kids come running up - he detonates. (beat) They’re saying fifty nine dead... She's heard this kind of story before and knows where it ends. She can’t bring herself to reply.
You know they need more bomb techs.
(handing James the carrots) Will you chop these up for me?
Boing! Boing! Boing! INT JAMES' SON’S BEDROOM LATER THAT NIGHT Bedtime. James is putting his son to sleep in a room decorated with mobiles and colorful wall hangings. He set the mobile spinning.  116

Boing! Boing! The boy giggles and reaches up. On the bed is a Jack-In-the-Box, which James picks up and winds. He opens the toy for his son who squeals with deli eyes wide with admiration for his daddy. Daddy, however, isn’t sure where to go with this..An odd moment for the w man of Baghdad: playing the awkward dad to his adoring ch James looks into his son’s unconditionally loving eyes. Something he sees there prompts a confession:

You love playing with that, don’t you..? You love all your stuffed animals. You love your Mommy, your Daddy. You love your pajamas... You love everything, don’t you? James playfully spins the mobile. The boy laughs at the whirring color.

But you know what buddy, as you get older some of the things that you love might not seem so special anymore. You know? Like your Jack- in-the-Box. The boy touches the Jack-in-the-Box, smiling beautifully.

Maybe... you'll realize it’s just a piece of tin and a stuffed animal. And the older you get, the fewer things you really love. (beat) By the time you get to be my age, maybe it’s only one -- or two -- things. James pauses. His son continues to giggle and play.
With me, I think it’s one.
--sonic overload of a C-130 airplane landing. Wheels touch down on tarmac.

The hydraulics of a loading ramp engage, lowering the ram and revealing a troop of young SOLDIERS inside the belly the plane. Passing over their frightened faces, we find one man who looks remarkably at ease. James. The soldiers disembark and we follow James as he leaves t plane and greets a another young EOD SOLDIER who has been waiting for him on the tarmac.

Welcome to Delta-Company. James shakes his hand. A Middle-Eastern sun bathes James’ upturned face lengthen into a smile. His pace slows...the tarmac transitions to dirt as little puffs of dust lift off his continuous passage. He is now in the bomb suit and we are --

On yet another war-torn street. Two fresh faced EOD SOLDIERS observe James as he makes another lonely walk down an empty block... heading to a b -- James' face glistening with pleasure -- The noon day sun shimmers on his helmet shield
DAYS LEFT IN DELTA COMPANY’S ROTATION: 365  118 And we watch him go down the unnamed road until he disappears.
